articles.title: Carlo Acutis: From a baptism in London to the first millennial saint
articles.summary: Before his death at 15, Carlo Acutis was known for his love of technology and had created a website to document miracles.
articles.content:
Carlo Acutis: From a baptism in London to the first millennial saint

5 hours ago Share Save Aleem Maqbool BBC Religion Editor Share Save

BBC Carlo Acutis will become the first millennial saint

A London-born boy is set to become the first millennial saint, in a ceremony steeped in an ancient ritual presided over by Pope Leo on Sunday. In his short life, Carlo Acutis created websites documenting "miracles" as a means of spreading Catholic teaching, leading some to nickname him God's influencer. His canonisation had been due in late April, but was postponed following the death of Pope Francis. More than a million people are estimated to have made a pilgrimage to the Italian hilltop town of Assisi where Carlo's body lies, preserved in wax.

But there is another pilgrimage site associated with Carlo Acutis that has seen an increase in visitors since it was announced that he was to be made a saint - Our Lady of Dolours Church in London. The font at the back of the Roman Catholic church in the Chelsea area was where Carlo was baptised as a baby in 1991. To the side of the church an old confession booth has been converted into a shrine to him. In it, a relic holder contains a single strand of Carlo's hair. "His family were in finance and they were working really temporarily in London," says Father Paul Addison, a friar at the church. "Although they didn't use the church much, they decided to come and ask to have the child baptised. So Carlo was a flash, a very big flash, in the life of the parish community," he says.

Father Paul Addison shows the font where Carlo was baptised in 1991

Carlo was not yet six months old when his parents moved back to their home country of Italy, and he spent the rest of his life in Milan. There, he was known for a love of technology and is said to have enjoyed playing video games. While some who knew Carlo Acutis say he did not appear to be especially devout, as a teenager he did create a website – pages of which are now framed at the church in Chelsea – in which miracles were documented.

Pages of Carlo's website are now framed at Our Lady of Dolours Church in Chelsea

But he died of leukaemia aged just 15. In the years after his death, Carlo's mother, Antonia Salzano, visited churches around the world to advocate for him to be a saint. As part of the process, it had to be proved her son had performed "miracles". "The first miracle, he did the day of the funeral," says Carlo's mother. "A woman with breast cancer prayed (for) Carlo and she had to start chemotherapy and the cancer disappeared completely," she explains.

Antonia Salzano has spent years advocating for her son to be made a saint

articles.personality_title: Carlo Acutis: The first millennial saint who used technology to share miracles
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Carlo Acutis was a boy born in London in 1991 who later lived in Italy. He loved technology and created a website to share stories about religious miracles before he died young from leukaemia at age 15.

**What happened** – Carlo Acutis will officially become the first millennial saint in a ceremony led by the Pope. His baptism took place in a church in London, which now has a shrine with a relic from him. Millions have visited the town in Italy where he is buried, and the church in London has also seen more visitors since the announcement.

**Impact** – Carlo’s use of technology to spread religious stories was unusual for a young person and helped many learn about Catholic faith in a new way. His story connects modern life with ancient religious traditions and has inspired people worldwide to visit places important to him.

**What's next step** – The canonisation ceremony will officially recognize Carlo as a saint. This might encourage more young people to use technology positively and could lead to more pilgrimages to places linked to him.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Carlo Acutis became the first millennial saint by combining his love for technology with his faith, inspiring many through his story and work.

Son baptême a eu lieu dans une église à Londres, qui possède maintenant un sanctuaire avec une relique de lui. Son histoire relie la vie moderne aux traditions religieuses anciennes et a inspiré des personnes dans le monde entier à visiter les lieux qui lui sont liés.

articles.personality_title_es: Carlo Acutis: El primer santo millennial que usó la tecnología para compartir milagros
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Carlo Acutis fue un niño nacido en Londres en 1991 que luego vivió en Italia. Le encantaba la tecnología y creó un sitio web para compartir historias sobre milagros religiosos antes de morir joven de leucemia a los 15 años.

**Qué pasó** – Carlo Acutis será oficialmente el primer santo millennial en una ceremonia dirigida por el Papa. Fue bautizado en una iglesia de Londres, que ahora tiene un santuario con una reliquia suya. Millones han visitado el pueblo en Italia donde está enterrado, y la iglesia en Londres también ha recibido más visitantes desde el anuncio.

**Impacto** – El uso de la tecnología por parte de Carlo para compartir historias religiosas fue inusual para alguien joven y ayudó a muchas personas a conocer la fe católica de una manera nueva. Su historia une la vida moderna con antiguas tradiciones religiosas e inspira a personas en todo el mundo a visitar lugares importantes para él.

**Próximo paso** – La ceremonia de canonización reconocerá oficialmente a Carlo como santo. Esto podría animar a más jóvenes a usar la tecnología de forma positiva y aumentar las peregrinaciones a lugares relacionados con él.

**Resumen en una frase** – Carlo Acutis se convirtió en el primer santo millennial combinando su amor por la tecnología con su fe, inspirando a muchos a través de su historia y su trabajo.
